title: Keystone Mastery Ideas for Vision
body:
Since Riot's mentioned they want more keystones, why not make one that centers around improving your ability to contribute vision for your team? Supports (and some junglers) would like that, I'm sure.
Here are some ideas:

Sentinel's Vigilance:
Your ward cap increases by 1. Gain a small amount of armor and magic resist, scaling with your level, for each green and/or pink ward you have active. The resistances do not apply until six seconds after placing a ward, and last until they expire or are destroyed.

Banisher of Shadows:
When you place a ward, for a few seconds it provides greatly increased vision range and highlights hidden enemies, as well as granting you a shield for a few seconds (on a long cooldown).

Scouting Sprite:
Your champion is followed by a small glowing orb that has the same sight radius as you, and trails behind you at around a 2-second delay. If you use the last charge in your Sightstone, it disappears and replenishes one charge, reappearing once you recall. If you die while it's active, it transforms into a blue ward.

Swiftrunner's Guidance: (inspiration credit to vSynthesize)
Wards you place last 15% longer, and generate a buff over a period of time (scales down with level, somewhere around 30-10 seconds) that surrounds them with a windy circle. When an ally walks into the circle, the buff is consumed, imbuing  them with a burst of movement speed. This wind is faintly visible to enemies.

Prophet of Retribution: (inspiration credit to The Djinn)
Your wards are protected by a shield that absorbs the damage from one attack. This shield recharges after 20-5s (scales down with level). An enemy that breaks this shield suffers an 80% slow that decays over 3 seconds, and is revealed for that duration.

I know these are pretty niche, but I think broadening the options of keystone masteries to include vision effects are a great way to make the support role more dynamic and fun. Feel free to give feedback on these ideas and contribute your own!

replies.body:
As a support main, I would absolutely love something that either increased my ward cap or increases the max charges on sightstone items by one (or both?)

With sightstone only having 3 wards, I feel like it's difficult to really advance vision without a substantial amount of help from your team. They keep making these vision changes with the thought of spreading the vision responsibility across the team. It's great in theory, but no amount of changes they make will actually get your allies to help enough with warding in silver...

I totally agree with you. Spreading vision responsibility across the team is a big reason the support role feels a bit bland now. Vision keystones would be a good way to fix that, I think.

My third idea is effectively a sightstone charge cap increase, giving you a free charge when you use the last one, at the cost of your extra vision behind you. Do you think that works?

All those ideas seem cool, but my reservation is that it would probably become expected/required that the support goes into vision for their keystone, making them feel like they can't take other cool ones. For example, i'd really miss windspeakers for Janna and Nami (my favorite two supports atm). It actually feels really rewarding to run that, to me.

What I'd almost prefer is a Tier 4 mastery in either cunning or resolve that only increases sightstone ward count by 1. This way, even if you feel required to take it as support, you don't feel like you're losing out on another major point of power. It would also enable others who utilize sightstone (some junglers) to access that mastery without sacrificing their preferred keystone as well.

Yeah, it's definitely a weird position to be put in for trade offs, but when you have to sacrifice heal/shield potential, you can make the vision capabilities that much stronger. Ideally it'd be a choice for non-enchanter Mage supports (Velkoz supp is my go-to) as a way to give them power other than damage.

> [{quoted}](name=Traxicus,realm=NA,application-id=A8FQeEA8,discussion-id=H8VxIWtk,comment-id=,timestamp=2016-02-09T14:06:34.343+0000)
> Sentinel's Vigilance:
> Your ward cap increases by 1. Gain a small amount of armor and magic resist, scaling with your level, for each ward you have active. The resistances apply three seconds after placing a ward.

I like the ward cap increase, but I'm not sold on the rest -- it encourages poor ward use in a fight by giving you a bonus for dropping a bunch quickly.

Perhaps just gain a small amount of armor / magic resist for each ward you have on the map? No timer applied.


> Banisher of Shadows:
> When you place a ward, for a few seconds it provides greatly increased vision range and highlights hidden enemies, as well as granting you a shield for a few seconds (on a long cooldown).

Seems a bit too good, honestly. It does EVERYTHING a support wants, and grants huge power to initiating supports. :P

> Scouting Sprite:
> Your champion is followed by a small glowing orb that has the same sight radius as you, and trails slightly behind you (It can't see in brushes you don't have vision of). If you use the last charge in your Sightstone, it disappears and replenishes one charge, reappearing once you recall. If you die while it's active, it transforms into a blue ward.

This one is pretty interesting. I'd probably cut the Sightstone part (tying masteries to items feels weird), but the rest is pretty solid. I'd actually allow it to see in bushes though -- gives it more strategic use.

> Windrunner's Guidance: (inspiration credit to vSynthesize)
> Wards you place last 15% longer, and generate a buff over a period of time (scales down with level, approx. 20-8 seconds) that, when an ally walks over them, imbues them with a burst of movement speed.

This one I absolutely love. Although maybe make it a minor Scuttle Crab buff -- movement speed in a radius around the ward. I'd also suggest that this might need to be tuned to make your wards always visible as a trade-off for the power it can grant.

---------------------------

Other suggestions:

**EXPERT SCOUT**: Your ward placement range is increased by 25%. You gain a 30% movement speed buff for 3 seconds after placing a ward (15 second cooldown).

*Allows for more daring ward placements, as you have an in-built method of escaping.*

---

**PROTECTIVE TOTEM**: When you place a ward, it raises a ring around it until the ward turns invisible. Enemies passing through the ring while it is active are slowed by 20% (+3% per level) for 2 seconds.

*Gives wards an extra utility case, which can add some zoning / CC to a support's kit.

> Sentinel's Vigilance:
> it encourages poor ward use in a fight by giving you a bonus for dropping a bunch quickly.
> Perhaps just gain a small amount of armor / magic resist for each ward you have on the map? No timer applied.

It's hard to avoid that edge case with what I'm going for here. I could limit it to wards placed a certain amount of time ago, that are in brush or a certain distance away, but maybe it's just not the right way to approach it.

> Banisher of Shadows:
> Seems a bit too good, honestly. It does EVERYTHING a support wants, and grants huge power to initiating supports. :P

Does it? It gives them no damage, no speed, and I'd imagine the shield isn't for very much. Remember, they'd choose this over Windspeaker's Blessing or Thunderlord's, so it has to bring something of comparable value. Still, the goal is they'd all be appealing to supports, so I'll consider that a success :)

> Scouting Sprite:
> This one is pretty interesting. I'd probably cut the Sightstone part (tying masteries to items feels weird), but the rest is pretty solid. I'd actually allow it to see in bushes though -- gives it more strategic use.

Maybe? Essentially the goal was to raise the charge cap on sightstone items, but in an interesting and interactive way. I think near-permanent vision into surrounding brush would be OP though. Remember, unless you have a sightstone and you use all its charges, this orb is always a few feet behind you.

> Swiftrunner's Guidance:
> This one I absolutely love. Although maybe make it a minor Scuttle Crab buff -- movement speed in a radius around the ward. I'd also suggest that this might need to be tuned to make your wards always visible as a trade-off for the power it can grant.

Yeah, maybe it'd manifest as a windy circle that would be visible to enemies? They wouldn't straight up see the ward and be able to attack it, but they'd know your ward was there.

> **EXPERT SCOUT**: Your ward placement range is increased by 25%. You gain a 30% movement speed buff for 3 seconds after placing a ward (15 second cooldown).

It's a good benefit, but it's not very interactive. Maybe it could be some kind of charge system where, once every minute or two, you can place a regular ward at blue trinket range (or something close)?

> **PROTECTIVE TOTEM**: When you place a ward, it raises a ring around it until the ward turns invisible. Enemies passing through the ring while it is active are slowed by 20% (+3% per level) for 2 seconds.

I'd be hesitant about ward effects with direct offensive uses. Other than that glitch where you can trap people by tower with blue trinket (think that was fixed) there's very little case for this in-game. I'd feel that encourages poor ward use way more than the Sentinel's Vigilance.

I think you can avoid the edge case by inverting it, actually. Have Wards grant a bonus once they have been active for more than 15 or 20 seconds. When you move out the case of using them in combat, although you do potentially encourage putting them in more defensive positions. Not necessarily a bad thing.


> Does it? It gives them no damage, no speed, and I'd imagine the shield isn't for very much. Remember, they'd choose this over Windspeaker's Blessing or Thunderlord's, so it has to bring something of comparable value. Still, the goal is they'd all be appealing to supports, so I'll consider that a success :)

I think wide-range vision into bushes is powerful enough, and the shield is not particularly necessary. I would also definitely need an internal cool down, which could get frustrating if you needed to save the ability but also need to ward somewhere else. Maybe power up the ability, but make it only work for vision wards? Then raise your vision Ward cap specifically to 2.


> Maybe? Essentially the goal was to raise the charge cap on sightstone items, but in an interesting and interactive way. I think near-permanent vision into surrounding brush would be OP though. Remember, unless you have a sightstone and you use all its charges, this orb is always a few feet behind you.

Well, it would only be vision into a bush that you gone into, so you still have to expose yourself to danger. I was imagining it as something like echo, where after X seconds it would eventually move to your position, so you couldn't get permanent vision.

> Yeah, maybe it'd manifest as a windy circle that would be visible to enemies? They wouldn't straight up see the ward and be able to attack it, but they'd know your ward was there.

Perfect.

> It's a good benefit, but it's not very interactive. Maybe it could be some kind of charge system where, once every minute or two, you can place a regular ward at blue trinket range (or something close)?

Hm. Could work. The goal was to be less interactive though: closer to wind speakers blessing than most of the other masters. It helps you do what you are supposed to do more efficiently: in this case, warding and getting back to position.

> I'd be hesitant about ward effects with direct offensive uses. Other than that glitch where you can trap people by tower with blue trinket (think that was fixed) there's very little case for this in-game. I'd feel that encourages poor ward use way more than the Sentinel's Vigilance.

The reason I like this one better than sentinels vigilance is because this has a clearer use case. It's hard to tell in advance when a minor defensive boost will save you, but it's easy to tell when a zoning slow will be a big impact to your team. That said, you may be correct that an offensive ward use is not the best idea.

> Have Wards grant a bonus once they have been active for more than 15 or 20 seconds.

I think we're vying for the same point here - it's not clear the way I wrote it but I was thinking the resistances would not take effect until three seconds after you place the ward, and would then last until they expire or are destroyed.
 
> Well, it would only be vision into a bush that you gone into, so you still have to expose yourself to danger. 

I guess that's sensible - and yeah, it'd basically be an Ekko clone, but only on maybe a 2 second delay.

> [{quoted}](name=Traxicus,realm=NA,application-id=A8FQeEA8,discussion-id=H8VxIWtk,comment-id=,timestamp=2016-02-09T14:06:34.343+0000)STUFF

Adding some more thoughts, because you've got a good bunch of ideas, and you enjoy conversing about design.

------------------------

**RESTORATIVE TOTEM:** Vision Wards you place give off a small aura that heals allies for 0.5% (+.05% per level) of their maximum health per second as long as they remain in range. This effect is disabled for wards placed close to allied towers.

*Might allow for interesting situations where you use a ward to heal up your team before a fight, or where you can create gameplay objective in lane by using a Vision Ward defensively.*
-----------------------
**SUPERB CLARITY:** Wards you place have a small triggering radius around then. If an enemy champion passes directly through this radius, their location is pinged on the map and they are *revealed* to your team for 6 seconds.

*Rewards unexpected or skillful ward placement, and perhaps makes melee champions hesitant about clearing even known wards.*

Hey, thanks! I took a break from the boards for a while, but a game design class I'm in this semester made me miss the discussions, so I came back. So far so good :)

> heals allies over time

Good call on disabling that near towers, but I think it might be weird to create an incentive for people to just hang around wards. The easy solution to that is to make it heal a more significant amount on a longer cooldown, but then it becomes similar to the Swiftrunner one, and then it raises the question if the "heal my allies" keystone is maybe already done better with WIndspeaker's...

> Superb Clarity

Ooh, that's neat. I especially like creating different approaches between melee and ranged champions. There's something to be said for accuracy in warding, and I'd really like to see some sort of implementation of that Mandrake Ward idea they had going (which this reminds me of), but I wonder if it'd just feel like random chance whether or not enemies walk through it directly or not. Sure, you could ward the most optimal pathing points, but in a context where this mastery is popular, would people start taking slightly unconventional routes? Is that bad? Who knows!

If we were to focus on the "some might find it risky to clear this ward" idea, could there be a way for a ward being cleared to "fight back" in some way? Probably not attack per se, but create danger that changes the attacker's mind? I wonder if it would be overpowered to reduce that champion's resistances in addition to revealing them. It might make them think twice about finishing it off.
